title: Nucleolar reorganization on stress depends on physicochemical changes due to nascent rRNA synthesis
summary: Successive maturation of ribosomal subunits occurs through multi-layered phase-separated structures of the cell nucleolus. The spatio-functional relationship between transcription of rRNA and nucleolar substructures and how this adapts to cellular stress remain incompletely understood. In this study, we resolve the sub nucleolar structures using expansion microscopy to reveal ordered structures of fibrillar center (FC) and dense fibrillar component (DFC) domains as nested shells, which is reorganized upon cellular stress like DNA damage or RNA polymerase I (RNAPI) inhibition. Direct visualization of nascent (5' ETS) and mature (28S) rRNA suggested that rRNA synthesis is the critical regulator of nucleolar size, and organization. Nucleolar reorganization upon stress emerges to be a direct function of nascent rRNA levels. Stress-induced transcription inhibition remodels the sub-nucleolar compartments from a viscoelastic state into solid-like condensates thereby perturbing the nucleolar pH gradient due to the missing rRNA scaffold. We show, that rather than signalling to mediate rDNA repair, nucleolar reorganization naturally arises primarily from reduced rRNA levels and the resultant biophysical restructuring of the nucleolus under cellular stress.

analysis_result.summary: Expansion microscopy shows nucleolar FC/DFC shell architecture reorganizes under stress primarily because reduced nascent rRNA transcription alters condensate material properties (viscoelastic to solid-like) and disrupts physicochemical gradients, highlighting RNA-driven phase behavior relevant to biophysical self-organization.

title: Recent Production Rates Of Cosmogenic Nuclides In The Igneous Rocks of Jezero Crater Floor, Mars
summary:
The Perseverance rover has collected rock samples from the floor of Jezero crater, Mars, set to be returned to Earth through the Mars Sample Return (MSR) mission. These surface rocks are continuously bombarded by cosmic rays, resulting in the formation of cosmogenic nuclides. To accurately date these rocks and understand past geological events, precise estimates […]

The post Recent Production Rates Of Cosmogenic Nuclides In The Igneous Rocks of Jezero Crater Floor, Mars appeared first on Astrobiology.

analysis_result.summary: Quantifies cosmogenic nuclide production in Perseverance’s Jezero crater igneous samples to improve surface exposure/age estimates—useful Mars context for reconstructing timelines of potentially habitable conditions, though not directly focused on origins-of-life mechanisms.

title: Authigenic Biosignatures Of Microbial Biomass Preserved As Carbonate Ooids Formed By Abiotic Chemically Oscillating Reactions Throughout Earth History
summary:
Ooids are small spheroidal carbonate grains that have circularly concentric and radially aligned crystals. Oolitic carbonates are commonly associated with fossils or organic matter, which has led to hypothetical formation models involving both biological and abiotic processes. The most commonly invoked model involves precipitates from supersaturated CaCO3 water under high-energy conditions. However, this model does […]

The post Authigenic Biosignatures Of Microbial Biomass Preserved As Carbonate Ooids Formed By Abiotic Chemically Oscillating Reactions Throughout Earth History appeared first on Astrobiology.

analysis_result.summary: This study argues that carbonate ooids can form via abiotic chemically oscillating reactions while still preserving authigenic microbial biomass, sharpening how we interpret carbonate “biosignatures” (and potential abiotic mimics) in ancient Earth and planetary settings.

title: Heuristic Model On The Origin Of The Homochirality Of Life Heuristic Model On The Origin Of The Homochirality Of life
summary:

We propose a mechanism that places the root of life homochirality in the formation of phospholipid bilayer vesicles (liposomes). These liposomes are formed at the water-air interface from Langmuir layers and contain ribose, presumably delivered to Early Earth by […]

The post Heuristic Model On The Origin Of The Homochirality Of Life Heuristic Model On The Origin Of The Homochirality Of life appeared first on Astrobiology.

analysis_result.summary: An origins-of-life–focused heuristic model proposing that lipid vesicle (liposome) self-assembly at the water–air interface could drive the emergence of biomolecular homochirality, linking chirality to early protocell-like membrane formation and associated nucleic-acid building blocks.

analysis_result.summary: A conceptual review likely discussing how simplified rule-based models can capture emergent biological complexity, offering broad methodological context but no explicit focus on prebiotic chemistry or abiogenesis from the available metadata.

title: La conquête du temps, de l'Égypte à l'ère atomique
summary: En 2035, la disparition du temps universel coordonné marquera un basculement historique au profit du temps atomique international : pour la première fois, le temps officiel des humains ne dépendra plus du ciel ni de la Terre. Retour sur cinq millénaires d'efforts pour quantifier l'écoulement du temps.

analysis_result.summary: A historical overview of human timekeeping and the shift from UTC to an international atomic timescale, with no substantive connection to origins-of-life, astrobiology, habitability, or biosignatures.

title: Remodeling of non-coding RNA regulatory networks: Decoding the pathological mechanisms and new therapeutic paradigms of cardiovascular diseases
summary:
Publication date: March 2026

Source: Physics of Life Reviews, Volume 56

Author(s): Wangzheqi Zhang, Lei Duan, Changli Wang, Yan Liao, Rui Zhao, Zhaoyu Li, Haoling Zhang, Zengwu Wang, Jing-jing Zhang

analysis_result.summary: Review of non-coding RNA regulatory network remodeling in cardiovascular disease pathogenesis and therapeutics, with only tangential relevance to Origins of Life via modern RNA biology.

title: Evidence of upright walking found in 7-million-year-old Sahelanthropus fossils
summary: In recent decades, scientists have debated whether a seven-million-year-old fossil was bipedal—a trait that would make it the oldest human ancestor. A new analysis by a team of anthropologists offers powerful evidence that Sahelanthropus tchadensis—a species discovered in the early 2000s—was indeed bipedal by uncovering a feature found only in bipedal hominins.

analysis_result.summary: Anthropological reanalysis suggests the 7‑million‑year‑old Sahelanthropus tchadensis shows skeletal features consistent with habitual bipedalism, informing early hominin evolution but offering only indirect relevance to origins-of-life research.

title: Episodic positive selection structurally stabilizes the Arabidopsis CONSTANS-like gene COL5 indicating adaptive evolution
summary:
Scientific Reports, Published online: 03 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41598-025-34129-6

Episodic positive selection structurally stabilizes the Arabidopsis CONSTANS-like gene COL5 indicating adaptive evolution

analysis_result.summary: This study infers episodic positive selection acting on the Arabidopsis CONSTANS-like gene COL5, with structural analyses suggesting adaptive evolution via protein stabilization.

title: Two white-blooded fish, two paths: Icefish and noodlefish independently lose red blood cell function
summary: Antarctic icefish are famous for living without red blood cells, but they are not alone. A species of needle-shaped, warm-water fish called the Asian noodlefish also lacks hemoglobin and red blood cells. Like icefish, its veins are filled with translucent white blood, said H. William Detrich, professor emeritus of marine and environmental sciences, who collaborated with Chinese scientists on a paper about the strange aquatic creatures published in Current Biology.

analysis_result.summary: Comparative evolutionary physiology study showing two distantly related fish lineages independently lost hemoglobin/red blood cell function, offering only indirect astrobiology relevance via adaptation to environmental oxygen constraints in aquatic habitats.

title: Une alternative aux bisphénols de nos tickets de caisse : du bois !
summary: Se débarrasser de n’importe quel bisphénol dans nos tickets de caisse ou nos reçus de carte bancaire ? Des chimistes ont imaginé avoir recours à la lignine, un composé du bois, pour une solution "verte" et non-toxique.

analysis_result.summary: Reports a green-chemistry approach using wood lignin to replace bisphenols in thermal-paper receipts, with minimal direct relevance to origins-of-life or astrobiology.

title: Flowering plant origins: Dosage-sensitive genes suggest no whole-genome duplications in ancestral angiosperm
summary: Angiosperms, also known as flowering plants, represent the most diverse group of seed plants, and their origin and evolution have long been a central question in plant evolutionary biology. Whole-genome duplication (WGD), or polyploidization, is widely recognized as a key driver of the origin and trait evolution of both seed plants and angiosperms.

analysis_result.summary: Genomic analysis of dosage-sensitive genes in flowering plants argues against a whole-genome duplication in the ancestral angiosperm lineage, informing plant evolutionary history but only tangentially relevant to origins-of-life questions.
